instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COPMUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COPMUTING_ISNS? This is a typo of PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS When you see PPBUS_S5_HS_COPMUTING_ISNS, assume they meant to type PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
I get orange/green light.  Board does not power on or fan spin.

had some small spots of corrosion - replaced <RESISTOR>R1517</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C2450</CAPACITOR>

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.4
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.4
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COPMUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.4
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.07
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PPV3V_S0</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 0

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
You're probably missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>

Voltage of <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>?

I can't find <RESISTOR>R1517</RESISTOR> on my schematic by the way

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
I was rechecking work on the replaced caps and noticed this test point missing.  would this stop board from powering up?

[ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]29533._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
No missing that test point would at best cause issues in S0, but you're not even fully getting into S5

Voltage of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL>?
Voltage of <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL>?
Voltage of <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_P5VP3V3</SIGNAL> probed at <CAPACITOR>C7200</CAPACITOR>?
Voltage of Pin 12 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>? (Probed at the pin or otherwise as close as possible)

I'm suspecting <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> trouble

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.040
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> - 3.304
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> - 2.003
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> - 3.423
<CAPACITOR>C7200</CAPACITOR> - 8.4 (my does schematic not say <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_P5VP3V3</SIGNAL>.  it says <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>)
Pin 12 is <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.422

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7206</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7216</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7238</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7246</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR>/61 within specifications?

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> in Ohms?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7206</RESISTOR> - 247k
<RESISTOR>R7216</RESISTOR> - 1.248k ( this is off  will change)
<RESISTOR>R7238</RESISTOR> - 7.5
<RESISTOR>R7246</RESISTOR> - 1.250
<RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR> - 6.98 (this is off will change)
<RESISTOR>R7261</RESISTOR> - 7.00 (this is off will change)

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - .3-.4

is it weird that so many resistors are bad?  just wondering before i replace them.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="wirelessplanet, post: 29558"]is it weird that so many resistors are bad? just wondering before i replace them.[/QUOTE]

The resistors are all good, in almost all cases a resistor fails high resistance. The lower resistance measurements are simply because the electricity found a different way to flow


The resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is bad though, that shoudn't be so low.

Inject 1V into it and start with something like 2 Amps and increase after a while if nothing noticeable heats up. Only increase voltage if you're running into an amperage limit
Its probably a capacitor or IC shorted somewhere, see what heats up. Use alcohol when you have found a spot that is somewhat hot, unless you want to make the same mistake as me by burning the tip of your finger on a shitty 0402 capacitor thats burning hot ;)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message:
So i shouldn't replace them?

<RESISTOR>R7216</RESISTOR> should be 6.65k and i'm only getting 1.248
<RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR> should be 23.2 and i'm only getting 7
r7261should be 10 and i'm only getting 7

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: No, dont replace the resistors. Remove L7260, see which pad the short is on, and the inject power as Smiba has explained.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: so the power supply is maxing out at 1.5amps. <CAPACITOR>C9487</CAPACITOR> is the only thing that gets slightly warm, not boiling hot. its showed a short on multimeter so i removed and short was still there. any other ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: so i tried with freeze test instead.  found the shorted cap.  <CAPACITOR>C7290</CAPACITOR>.  now i have fan spin.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: To battle the supply maxing out: increase the voltage, the maximum allowed in this case is 3.3V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: should i be worried about that missing testpoint?  computer turns on and works now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a No Power
threads.message: Unlikely, I think if the PCH was missing its DAC voltage the system woudn't work or at least not pass AHT. Should be alright :)
